content:
Hi, I'm new to Lean and VS Code and I've been having problems using MIL to start learning. I've managed to get lean up and running by placing the 'mathematics_in_lean' folder inside '.elan' (though I don't know if this is how I'm supposed to make it work). I've also used 'git clone https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4' to clone the mathlib4 repository into '.elan'. However, inside any of the .lean files in MIL I get an error saying "unkown package 'Mathlib'" in the first line of code containing the 'import'. I haven't been able to find any help online regarding what to do, I feel like it's common knowledge for a programmer to use 'import' but I have no idea what I'm doing tbh. What should I do?
Thanks in advance.
Nothing will work if you put folders in random places instead of following instructions.

I've been trying to follow the instructions given in https://leanprover-community.github.io/install/project.html#working-on-an-existing-project, however when I run 'lake exe cache get' I get this error:

info: Downloading proofwidgets/v0.0.13/windows-64.tar.gz
error: > curl -s -f -o .\lake-packages\proofwidgets\build\windows-64.tar.gz -L https://github.com/EdAyers/ProofWidgets4/releases/download/v0.0.13/windows-64.tar.gz
error: external command curl exited with code 35
leantar is too old; downloading more recent version
uncaught exception: % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Time Time Current
Dload Upload Total Spent Left Speed
0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 0
curl: (35) schannel: next InitializeSecurityContext failed: Unknown error (0x80092012) - La funci≤n de revocaci≤n no puede comprobar la revocaci≤n para el certificado.

I've also tried to run: 'curl -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/master/lean-toolchain -o lean-toolchain' as it says in 'https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/wiki/Using-mathlib4-as-a-dependency' but I get an error too:

Invoke-WebRequest : No se encuentra ningún parámetro que coincida con el nombre del parámetro 'L'.
En línea: 1 Carácter: 6

  • curl -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover-community/mathli ...
  • ~~
    + CategoryInfo : InvalidArgument: (:) [Invoke-WebRequest], ParameterBindingException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NamedParameterNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeWebRequestCommand

This is why I tried to download mathlib4 manually. Regarding the placement of 'mathematics_in_lean' inside .elan, I did this as 'lake exe cache get' wasn't working if I didn't do so. How do I solve these errors?
You need to investigate that curl error, nothing will work otherwise.
Could you point me towards somewhere to start looking? I'm quite lost.
Google says https://weareag.co.uk/docs/worldline-hosted-checkout/troubleshooting-worldline-hosted-checkout/how-to-fix-localhost-error-curl-error-35-ssl-connect-error/
Okay, thanks. I'll see what I can do about it. I'll post again if I find an answer or bump into another roadblock.

No that is a very wrong hint. This site explains how to fix server configurations.

From the google translate of your error message it complains about the fact that it cannot verify that the certificate of the page it is trying to download things from is valid. But I don't know when this precise error happens. I'd guess if we had the english error message it would be easier google-able

Invoke-WebRequest : A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'L'.
At line:1 char:6
+ curl -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover-community/mathli ...
+      ~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [Invoke-WebRequest], ParameterBindingException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NamedParameterNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeWebRequestCommand
Okay so for the second error its just that windows' curl doesn't support the -L flag so we shouldn't try that. What about the (35) schannel one?

the (35) schannel one?

That's in the installation instructions, isn't it?

I'm going to restart my computer and change the language to english, it should then give me the errors in english and I'll send them

From the google translate of your error message it complains about the fact that it cannot verify that the certificate of the page it is trying to download things from is valid. ungood

No files to download
Decompressing 3757 file(s)
unpacked in 241 ms.

I don't have the actual download from when it worked since I restarted the pc after that.
So it works now yes?
I think this error is explained by https://github.com/leanprover-community/leanprover-community.github.io/pull/360

And for the record you can fix the other error by removing the -L tag, as in run 

curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/master/lean-toolchain -o lean-toolchain

Everything?

Thanks for telling me about the quotes, I'm new to zulip (and forums like this one in general) so any guidelines like this one to follow are welcome.

The error persists though
What is the error?

Whenever I go to any of the .lean files inside the MIL tutorial the following appears:
image.png
Rather, whenever the .lean file has an 'import' in it

Okay @Eric Wieser i changed the format of header-data.bmp a little bit. At the last doc-gen refactor I pulled some data that we don't need to keep globally (such as line numbers etc.) out of the global declarations-data.bmp into just the module specific ones so it only gets downloaded on demand. I now changed header-data.bmp to contain a different structure.
It's still a decl -> Info map but the info now looks like this:

{
    "info": {
        "sourceLink": "https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/blob/ec941735c80dc54c53948e30c428905b6600f95a/src/Init/Prelude.lean#L33-L33",
        "name": "id",
        "line": 33,
        "kind": "def",
        "docLink": "./Init/Prelude.html#id",
        "doc": "The clear text doc"
    },
    "header": "the HTML"
}

So you only need to download header-data.bmp and can work exclusively with that in your make_site script, is that acceptable?

@blackbirdsr you need to first move the mathematics in lean directory out of the elan directory, and then you need to open the mathematics in lean directory using VS Code's "open folder" functionality.

Thanks @Henrik Böving; that's fine, but some warning would have been great! I've made https://github.com/leanprover-community/leanprover-community.github.io/pull/364, if it doesn't pass CI would you mind helping me fix it?

Eric Wieser said:

Thanks Henrik Böving; that's fine, but some warning would have been great! I've made https://github.com/leanprover-community/leanprover-community.github.io/pull/364, if it doesn't pass CI would you mind helping me fix it?

Sure I'll help.

I thought I accounted for everything but I forgot about the fact that you don't only pull in header-data.bmp but also declaration-data.bmp /o\
@Eric Wieser it broke but I think you can handle that one :P
@blackbirdsr all this foo crap in .elan does not bode well either. You were very unwise to start putting stuff in there. Its name begins with a dot for a reason.

Kevin Buzzard ha dicho:

blackbirdsr you need to first move the mathematics in lean directory out of the elan directory, and then you need to open the mathematics in lean directory using VS Code's "open folder" functionality.

It worked! Thank you very much!

Thank you all for the help! I don't know if I would've been able to figure it out myself.

Ah, so you removed the declaration-data fields in one commit, but only just added them back to the header data?
Correct

@blackbirdsr, if you remember which guide this was, could you post a link, so we can hunt it down and destroy it? :-)
I found it: https://github.com/leanprover/vscode-lean4

Also, unfortunately I'm getting a similar yet different problem now. Before an error would appear in the 'Lean Infoview' like in this image:
image.png
Now, no error appears in the Lean Infoview tab and when I clicked on 'S02_Overview.lean' the infoview tab stated that Mathlib was building, after a while (around 20 minutes I'd say, though I think I restarted the process several times on accident) it finished doing so. However, when I try to run S02_Overview.lean I get the following error:

mathematics_in_lean\MIL\C01_Introduction> lean --run .\S02_Overview.lean
.\S02_Overview.lean:1:0: error: unknown package 'Mathlib'
You might need to open 'C:\Users\black\Mathematics in Lean' as a workspace in your editor

So I'm getting the error: unknown package 'Mathlib'again, but in a different place.
I ran lake exe cache get before Mathlib started building, in case that's relevant.
Well, I'm going to get some sleep. I'll get here again late tomorrow. Thanks again for all the help!
You can't lean --run a single file.
From the main directory of the project you can lake build MIL.C01_Introduction.S02_Overview.
Lean files in isolation don't have enough information to locate imports / identify the correct version of Lean to use, etc.
So you should use lake for everything, and run from the same location as your lakefile.lean.
does lake env lean --run work?

Scott Morrison ha dicho:

From the main directory of the project you can lake build MIL.C01_Introduction.S02_Overview.

It worked, thank you! I'll make sure tu use lake from there then.

Mario Carneiro ha dicho:

does lake env lean --run work?

It also worked :)

Mario Carneiro said:

does lake env lean --run work?

Very useful! Is it normal that it lags for a few seconds? I'm assuming this loads the libraries therefore takes time, but in fact I'm not sure...

If it does do that, then depending on what file you intend to run, could you reduce that time by loading less libraries?

Eric Wieser said:

the (35) schannel one?

That's in the installation instructions, isn't it?

It's now at https://leanprover-community.github.io/install/project.html

@Flo (Florent Schaffhauser) The lag is largely a factor of how many dependencies the Lake project you are calling lake env from has. So, if you use it in a project with none it will be faster than if you use in project that e.g. depends on mathlib.

Thanks @Mac Malone !

I see, yes. Since mathlib (which my project is indeed using) is quite large, it takes time to run a file that imports part of it, if I do that using the lake env lean --run Foo.lean command.

Specifically, my file Foo.lean imports Mathlib.Data.List.Defs, because I want to use the function List.sum in it. And I have managed to reduce the lag by running instead

LEAN_PATH=/path_to_project/lake-packages/mathlib/build/lib:/path_to_project/lake-packages/std/build/lib:/path_to_project/lake-packages/Qq/build/lib lean --run Foo.lean

But it is not efficient, because I first had to manually add /path_to_project/lake-packages/mathlib/build/lib then path_to_project/lake-packages/std/build/lib and finally /path_to_project/lake-packages/Qq/build/lib.

Presumably this would only get more cumbersome with a more complex Foo.lean file (see MWE below).

import Mathlib.Data.List.Defs

def my_list : List Nat := [1, 2, 3, 4]

def main : IO Unit := IO.println my_list.sum

Is the recommendation for such a MWE still to use lake env lean --run Foo.lean or is there a cleverer way about it?

@Flo (Florent Schaffhauser) At the moment, lake env lean is still the way to go. Lake is just not terribly efficient about it. If you want to speed up a number of lake env queries, you could run export `lake env | grep LEAN_PATH` to set the LEAN_PATH variable in your shell session to the value lake env computes.
With that, runs of just lean --run Foo.lean should work properly.
(not this will only work if there is not a space in the path. If there is a space you can use export "`lake env | grep LEAN_PATH`" (with quotes) instead
Thanks! But unfortunately, did not work. I get the same error Foo.lean:1:0: error: unknown package 'Mathlib'.
Oh, wait, let me see if there is a space somewhere :sweat_smile:
@Flo (Florent Schaffhauser) after the export, run echo $LEAN_PATH to see if it set it properly.
Worked like a charm, thanks!
Alternatively, you can also use lake env bash (or lake env whatever shell you are using) to start a shell session with the environment vars Lake sets.
There was no space in my path, but I missed the backticks in export `lake env | grep LEAN_PATH` , :flushed:
This is all super useful, thanks a lot :smiling_face:
blackbirdsr has marked this topic as resolved.
